thread.title: The fire truck Peoria donated to Ukraine just responded to its first call
thread.title_full: The fire truck Peoria donated to Ukraine just responded to its first call

author: @25newsweek
title: The fire truck Peoria donated to Ukraine just responded to its first call
text:
The fire truck Peoria donated to Ukraine just responded to its first call
PEORIA (25News Now) - After a decommissioned Peoria fire truck was given a second life overseas, locally-based organization US Ambulances for Ukraine received word Wednesday that it went on its first emergency response call.
“When you start to get feedback, or you get messages, or even pictures or videos. It’s great to know the vehicles are doing what you hope they would do,” said founder Chris Manson.
Tuesday night, volunteer firefighters in Ukraine used the truck to respond to a small fire in a building that had spread to nearby brush.
“To see that be able to be carried forward to a whole other country and to see that it can have a positive impact on the community, it makes us feel good inside,” said Peoria Fire Chief Shawn Sollberger.
In March, the Peoria City Council approved sending the decommissioned fire truck to Ukraine. US Ambulances for Ukraine vehicles are only used for humanitarian purposes.
Manson has traveled to Ukraine to deliver vehicles around nine times. He took the Peoria truck in May.
He and his team have had to take shelter before, but this was the first time they witnessed a large attack, as Ukraine’s war with Russia continues.
“It was really the first time seeing the anti-aircraft fire go up, seeing them actually hit their targets, you know, seeing explosions in the distance or over the city. So, that was a little unsettling,” Manson said.
Their efforts will continue, even after witnessing this violence. The organization is currently working to secure around fifteen more vehicles to donate. These cars, ambulances, and fire trucks will come from all over the United States.
In the meantime, the Peoria fire truck is there to answer calls.
“The citizens of Peoria, and the city council, the fire chief, can rest assured that the vehicle is doing what it’s supposed to be doing, living a good second life serving citizens in need,” Manson said.
